Award.AwardTitle: Transformative Concepts and Investigations for Piezoelectric Resonance Defined Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to explore mechanisms of nonlinear mechanical-optoelectronic coupling processes at frequencies defined by piezoelectric resonances and to develop a family of novel frequency elective signal processing devices that have exceptional properties, such as ultralow power microwave sensors and ultrafast/ultracompact photonic modulators. The approach is to study the principles governing the polarization and lattice phonon coupled phenomena at resonance, both by finite element analysis modeling and by conducting a series of carefully designed electrooptic and microwave-photonic experiments on piezoelectric resonators.

Intellectual Merits of the Project: The combined numerical and experimental investigations will reveal the defining parameters of the resonance process that combines contributions of the strain gradient, the local polarization, and the displacement current in a non-centre-symmetrical piezoelectric crystal-resonator. The project will lead to an essential understanding of the nonlinear multi-physics coupling process at resonance and to the development of engineering strategies that capture the substantial potential of the piezoelectric resonance defined electromagnetic interconnecting devices.

Boarder Impacts of the Project: The project is interdisciplinary requiring a broad range of knowledge including solid state physics, material science, and electrical engineering. It thus provides excellent research and education/training opportunities for graduate students. The PIs have been, and will continue to be, active in attracting and mentoring undergraduate students in research. The project will help the development of new graduate courses and strengthens the new PhD program in electronic devices at UTSA that is a Hispanic serving-institute with a fast growing engineering research program and a rich pool of underrepresented minority students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Although vibrations and waves are interwoven and utilized broadly by musicians and electrical engineers, existing knowledge dealing with dielectric materials has been treating the medium as a continuum characterized by macroscopic material parameters.  Some parameters such as dielectric permittivity, magnetic permeability, and mechanical density however are not well defined at resonance. Ferroelectric and piezoelectric materials belong to the family of non-centric symmetries. At resonance, charge separation takes place and incident electromagnetic waves will be influenced by charge and density gradients therefore transmit, reflect, or absorb differently. The understanding on resonance phenomena in piezoelectric is significant both from scientific point of view and for various sensor and actuator applications especially at high frequencies such as microwave and optical frequencies.  The project will lead to an essential understanding of the nonlinear multi-physics coupling process at resonance and to the development of engineering strategies that capture the substantial potential of the piezoelectric resonance defined electromagnetic interconnecting devices.

Intellectual Merits of the Project: The project achieved an in-depth understanding of the nonlinear multi-physics coupling process at resonance and enabled the development of engineering strategies that utilizes piezoelectric resonance defined electromagnetic interconnecting process for novel devices.

Multiphysics finite element analysis models have been constructed and implemented to evaluate the microscopic parameters when the crystal is vibrating and to simulate its admittance spectrum, electro-optic effect, photoelastic effect, and optical wave propagation. Experimental results obtained corroborated with these models and formed the new insights into the dynamic nature of the induced periodic displacement current in a piezoelectric resonator. Piezoresonance enhanced optical modulators have been demonstrated using modulating frequencies several orders lower than optical frequency and achieved an order higher electrooptic effect, compared to conventional modulators.

Piezoelectric resonance modulated THz wave propagation: The researchers explored THz frequency behavior of single crystal LiNbO3 films, and discovered the phase modulation property influenced by piezoelectric resonance at fundamental resonance frequency. The influence of periodic gradient structure on the enhancement of microwave transmission was also envisioned in this research. This work is significant as it is a direct and likely the first evidence of dynamic control of parametric amplification by piezoelectric resonance, which is the base for a recent technical invention disclosure for novel millimeter wave devices.

Piezoelectric Resonance and Coupled Multiferroic Effect in Core-Shell Nanoparticles: Multiferroic behavior of magnetoelectric nanoparticles, which exhibits both ferromagnetic and ferroelectric properties, finds significance in various applications. In this research work, doctoral researcher fabricated ferromagnetic-ferroelectic core shell nano particles and characterized their crystalline structure and their multiferroic properties. Their nanostructure, ferromagnetic and ferroelectric properties confirmed their single-crystalline structure, corroborated the multiferroic nature of these core-shell magneto-electric nano-particle (CSMEN). Intriguingly, it is found that the core-shell nanoparticles fabricated respond to applied magnetic (or electric) field differently under ac or dc conditions, and at select frequencies. It is possible to remotely excite and control the movement of the CSMEN to enter a giving biological cell, for example. The research has been performed on biomedical cells and has potential to contribute to drug delivery and biomedical imaging.

Funded or partially funded by the NSF grant, researchers working on and collaborating through this project have published 3 doctoral dissertations, 10 MS thesis, 14 journal papers, 7 conference papers, and filed 4 patents (2 provisional and 2 pending).

Broader Impact of the Project: The project is interdisciplinary requiring a broad range of knowledge including solid state physics, material science, and electrical engineering. It thus provides excellent research and education/training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students.

To date, this project has provided training, research, and professional development opportunities to Seven Doctoral students. Two of the doctoral graduates are employed by US high tech company and two hold university faculty positions. This project also provided training and professional development opportunities to more than 10 master’s students, most of them hired by US companies and three of them continued in doctoral programs. This project provided research exposure to seven undergraduate students and four high school students. The majority of the undergraduate students are underrepresented in STEM field. All high school students involved are entering STEM (one in medicine) field in universities.

The outcome of the research has been integrated in faculty PI/CoPI’s engineering courses on advanced sensors and on dielectric and optoelectronic devices. Students get hand-on exposure in both numerical and experimental techniques and are attracted to conduct interdisciplinary materials research at advanced levels. College of Engineering, UTSA, in 2012-2013 established a new Interdisciplinary Graduate Program in Advanced Materials Engineering and the faculty PI/CoPI have contributed to the establishment and growth of the interdisciplinary program.  Faculty PI/CoPI are actively engaged in the research community and have been leaders in ACerS and SPIE on electronic materials research.  The PI continues serve as faculty advisor of the UTSA Society of Women Engineers and is actively engaged with female students for improved retention and career success.
